questions.question: I met her in Ireland ………………………
questions.description: We use ago with a past tense and a past time expression to count back from the present.

questions.question: The two sisters are very much ………………………
Have you been here ……………………..?
questions.description: Before is used with a perfect tense and no time expression to mean ‘at any time before now/then.’

questions.question: ……………………….. the people were singing and dancing.
questions.description: All or all of can both be used before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: I would quite like to go out, …………………….. it is a bit late.
‘Lovely day.’ ‘Yes. Bit warm, ………………………..’
questions.description: Though can be used as an adverb. Although cannot be used as an adverb.

questions.question: It is important that she ………………………… told.
questions.description: In American English, the structure without should is more common.

questions.question: She looks ……………………… she is going to cry.
questions.description: Like is possible here in an informal style.

questions.question: Those candies were wonderful. Could I have …………………………… one?
questions.description: Another can mean ‘an additional or extra’. It is used after plural nouns.

questions.question: Those peas were delicious. Could I have ………………………..?
questions.description: With plural and uncountable nouns we normally use more, not other.

questions.question: I didn’t like ………………………. the movies.
questions.description: We use any of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: Prices keep ………………………
questions.description: Rise means get higher/go up. Arise means begin or appear.
